groundtruth: In Phase 1 dose expansion cohorts, patients with Microsatellite Stable (MSS) CRC can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For H&N cancer, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease. For melanoma, they can have no more than 3 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a BRAF inhibitor for patients with a BRAF mutation. For NSCLC, they can have no more than 2 lines of prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, including at least 1 prior treatment with a targeted therapy for patients with a mutation such as EGFR, ALK, KRAS, or RET. It's important to consider these criteria when enrolling patients in the dose expansion cohorts.

Understood, for an interventional study, there are normally three phases of a clinical trial: Phase 1, Phase 2 and Phase 3. Phase 1 focuses on clinical research such as determining the best way to give the intervention, determining how well it works, and finding the right dose of the experimental treatment. The objective of phase 2 is to confirm the results you get from phase 1. Phase 3 evaluates the long-term effects and safety. Because your study design is on an interventional, it is recommended to follow these three phase. In your study, it is considered clinical research. For this trial, Phase 0 is also considered in some clinical trials when the research questions relate to basic understanding of pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, or pharmacodynamics. Phase 0 research focuses on how patients respond to new experimental treatments. Phase 0 can include studies such as the absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion, and toxicity (ADME) studies of experimental drugs. The study phases do not have to be completed in order or at all, but are typically performed in that sequence.

Certainly! Here are some alternative methods for analyzing biomarkers in Cohort A:1. Peripheral tissue analyses: These include analyzing biomarkers in blood and accessible fluids like tear fluid, urine, and saliva. These fluids have less stringent collection protocols and may provide less-invasive biomarkers for PD detection. While some of these fluids are not yet widely used for biomarker research, recent studies have shown their potential for research on central nervous system diseases.2. Imaging biomarkers: Imaging biomarkers are useful non-invasive methods for identifying and tracking PD. Examples include volumetric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) with specific radiotracers. Imaging biomarkers can reveal changes in brain structure and neurotransmission that can lead to PD.3. Fluid-based potential protein biomarkers: Candidate biomarkers for PD are being discovered at a rapid rate, but many have yet to be validated in large trials. These biomarkers could include proteins directly linked to LRRK2 activity, such as p-Rab10 or p-ERK, and proteins in urine.4. Cystic-fluid biomarkers: Recently, studies have shown that cystic fluid, such as the intraduodenal ganglionic fluid from Parkin mouse model, contains protein biomarkers for PD. Collecting cystic fluid may allow for earlier detection of PD-related protein biomarkers.

This arm can be named "Experimental: finite arm." The participant group/arm would undergo the procedure of Zygomaticomaxillary fracture repair. We would start by using a cone beam CT scan to create a 3D scanned image of the Zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture. These 3D images will be introduced to finite element (FA) software to evaluate stresses, micromotion, and life time for each model. The analysis will help us determine the best point of fixation for the fracture. After applying this point of fixation on the patient, we would perform another round of finite element analysis to verify the results. This arm will provide valuable insights into the role of finite element analysis in selecting the optimal point of fixation for Zygomaticomaxillary complex fractures.

model_response: The study is designed as a phase 1 open-label, two-arm study. The study participants will be randomized in either the drug combination group or the control group. Participants assigned to the drug combination group will receive Ziv-aflibercept plus Cemiplimab. Participants assigned to the control group will receive Ziv-Aflibercept alone or placebo (which is an inactive substance that is similar to Cemiplimab) plus Cemiplimab in the same dose.

The combination of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept is an experimental treatment, and there is no prior experience with treating metastatic uveal melanoma using these two agents in combination. Therefore, in the absence of any data on the best dosing schedule of these agents, the schedule chosen is based on the pharmacodynamics (PD) and pharmacokinetics (PK) characteristics of the individual Ziv-Aflibercept and Cemiplimab drugs. PK and PD data from single-agent studies with Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept are being evaluated to determine the optimal dosing schedule for each drug. This combination trial design was chosen based on the PK and PD profiles of Cemiplimab and Ziv-Aflibercept when administered individually. Studies showed that Cemiplimab PK is not impacted when it is administered along with other concomitant anticancer agents, and its maximum serum concentrations are not affected by other coadministered drugs. Therefore, the schedule of Cemiplimab being given every 3 weeks was deemed suitable. Studies also showed that when Ziv-Aflibercept is given along with other agents, its Cmax (the maximum plasma concentration that is achieved during the first dosing interval for a drug) is approximately two-fold higher than when Ziv-Aflibercept is given alone. Therefore, the schedule of Ziv-Aflibercept being given every 2 weeks was deemed suitable.

As with any experimental treatment, the combination therapy used in this study may cause adverse effects in some participants. However, the goal of the study is to determine the safety and efficacy of the treatment, so the potential benefits outweigh the risks. For example, the study aims to find alternative treatment options for patients with metastatic uveal melanoma, who do not have many effective options currently available. Additionally, the study provides an opportunity for participants to receive treatment with a novel, investigational agent, which may help to slow or stop the progression of their disease. The clinical trial also involves regular monitoring of participants to ensure the safety of the treatment and identify any potential side effects. If the treatment combination is found to be effective, it could potentially provide significant benefits to patients with similar types of cancer. The design of the study aims to collect the necessary data to determine the safety, effectiveness, and appropriate use of the treatment combination in this particular group of patients.

Intervention Details:
- Ziv-Aflibercept is an investigational or experimental anti-cancer agent that inactivates vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) from functioning. It has been shown to prevent the formation of new blood vessels in tumors and inhibit tumor growth. Blocking VEGF may also enhance the immune response against cancer.
- Cemiplimab is a human monoclonal anti-PD-1 antibody that works by blocking the programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor on immune cells. This helps enhance the immune response against cancer cells.

Here are the study arms:

1. Experimental Group (Stress Ball):
- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the experimental group will be given a stress ball before the subcutaneous injection during the routine daytime treatment of the ward at 10:00. They will be asked to squeeze the stress ball with their hand on the opposite extremity of the upper extremity where the subcutaneous injection will be applied, counting to five, and then to relax their hand. In the meantime, 0.4 ml of LMWH will be administered by subcutaneous route according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the Visual Analog Scale (VAS).
- Intervention/Treatment: Stress ball use during subcutaneous injection.
- Purpose: To investigate the effect of stress ball use on pain during subcutaneous injection.

2. Control Group:
- Participant Group/Arm: The patients in the control group will not receive any intervention before the subcutaneous injection. They will receive 0.4 ml of LMWH administered by the nurse in the routine daytime treatment of the service at 10:00, according to the doctor's request. The level of pain in the area where the subcutaneous injection was applied will be evaluated with the VAS.

groundtruth:
Thank you for providing all the necessary details. Based on the information you've shared, I can suggest the following study arms:

1. Experimental: Cohort A - In this study arm, patients with high and undetermined risk of fibrosis (bf+) will receive adaptive breast cancer radiotherapy using ETHOS. The intervention for this arm is Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy.

2. Active Comparator: Cohort B - In this study arm, patients with low risk of fibrosis (bf-) will receive conventional intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT). The intervention for this arm is Conventional IMRT.

These study arms will allow us to compare the outcomes of adaptive radiotherapy with ETHOS in high-risk patients (Cohort A) to conventional IMRT in low-risk patients (Cohort B). By assessing the efficacy and safety of adaptive radiotherapy in hypersensitive patients with high locoregional risk breast cancer, we can evaluate the potential benefits of personalized treatment and determine its impact on locoregional control and toxicity outcomes.

In Cohort A, the target volume for adaptive radiotherapy using ETHOS (Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy) is defined as PTV = CTV + 2 mm (except for IMC with 5mm), excluding 5mm beneath the skin. On the other hand, in Cohort B, the target volume for conventional IMRT is defined as PTV = CTV + 7mm, excluding 5mm beneath the skin. These target volume differences are designed to accommodate the specific needs of each treatment modality and the risk profiles of the patients in each cohort.

Certainly! Here are the full study arms:

Study Arms:
1. Experimental: Cohort A - In cohort A, for patients with high and undetermined risk of fibrosis (bf+), an adaptive breast cancer radiotherapy (ETHOS) will be delivered.
Intervention/Treatment: Radiation: Treatment ETHOS radiotherapy
- Cohort A: Adaptive RT: PTV = CTV + 2 mm (except for IMC with 5mm), excluding 5mm beneath the skin

2. Active Comparator: Cohort B - In cohort B, for patients with low risk of fibrosis (bf-), conventional intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT) will be delivered.
Intervention/Treatment: Radiation: Conventional IMRT
- Cohort B: IMRT: PTV = CTV + 7mm, excluding 5mm beneath the skin

These study arms will allow us to evaluate the efficacy and safety of adaptive radiotherapy with ETHOS compared to conventional IMRT, and assess the impact of treatment modality on locoregional control and toxicity outcomes.

Certainly! Let's start with the active comparator for the adaptive phenotypes. This group will consist of the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups. Participants will be administered Dupilumab (Dupixent), an interleukin-4 receptor alpha antagonist. They will also be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The goal is to evaluate the efficacy of Dupilumab in individuals with adaptive phenotypes.

The experimental group for maladaptive phenotypes will also be divided into Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. Participants in this group will receive Dupilumab (Dupixent) and undergo exposure to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The purpose is to assess the effectiveness of Dupilumab in individuals with maladaptive phenotypes and compare the treatment response between adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes.

The placebo comparator arms will mirror the adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes. Participants in the Adaptive-A and Adaptive-B subgroups will receive an inert placebo instead of the active drug but will still be exposed to House Dust Mites (HDM) in the aeroallergen challenge chamber. The same applies to the Maladaptive-A and Maladaptive-B subgroups. These arms are important for establishing a baseline response in adaptive and maladaptive phenotypes when not receiving the active drug.

Certainly! In the Experimental: Active tDCS arm, participants will undergo five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of active transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly active tDCS sessions preceding the scheduled yoga sessions. The tDCS sessions will involve the administration of a constant anodal current of 2 mA for 20 minutes, targeting the primary motor cortex contralateral to the most painful site. The yoga program will be led by a certified instructor and will consist of centring, warming up, yoga postures, and guided relaxation.

In the Sham Comparator: Sham tDCS arm, participants will attend five in-person visits in Week 1 for the administration of sham transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS). From Weeks 2 to 9, they will receive weekly sham tDCS sessions before the scheduled yoga sessions. The sham tDCS sessions will mimic the sensation of current without actual stimulation. Participants will also participate in the same yoga program led by a certified instructor.

Sure, here are the detailed interventions and treatment for the active comparator arm: Patients will be divided into two groups, randomized with equal probability: Group 1 to the intervention arm and Group 2 to the active comparator arm. Patients randomized to Group 1 (DCCV + PVI) will undergo general anesthesia with either a femoral or a tibial access, followed by DC cardioversion and pulmonary vein isolation (PVI: circumferential ablation lines at antral and left anterior of each vein) using a three-dimensional electroanatomical mapping system. During the procedure, heparin will be administered targeting a partial thromboplastin time (PTT) at 60–80 seconds and maintaining the electrode catheter in the pulmonary veins with the patient on continuous electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring. The interruptions during radio-frequency ablation (RFA) procedures due to ventricular arrhythmias will be managed with electrical cardioversion. The PVI will be documented and will be followed by a detailed echocardiography study at the end of the procedure. Patients randomized to Group 2 (DCCV) will only undergo either a femoral or a tibial approach for DC cardioversion and will not be subjected to the PVI procedure or pulmonary vein isolation. Inclusion criteria for randomization to either DCCV + PVI or DCCV include: a signed consent form and age 18‒90 years old. Exclusion criteria for randomization include: an estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <60 mL/min/1.73 m2; or any condition contraindicating anti-coagulation, such as mechanical heart valve position, prosthetic valve with valve insufficiency, symptomatic hypertension, and history of bleeding disorders (such as coagulopathy, hematological cancer, etc.).

Certainly! Stable isotopes are isotopes of an element that have the same chemical properties as the unstable isotopes but a different number of nuclei. The number of nuclei is referred to as the atomic mass. For example, in 2H, 2 is the atomic mass, whereas 1 is the atomic mass for the unstable isotope, 1H or protium, as it is known. Stable isotopes become radiolabeled by replacing an unstable nucleus with a stable isotope. After incubated in the human body, stable isotopes are released steadily into the bloodstream, making them a suitable marker for the albumin catabolic rate.

In clinical studies, it is recommended to have an "active comparison group" as a control. This means that the control group should receive some type of intervention that is considered active or beneficial. In the case of this study, the "sham myofunctional therapy" or a placebo intervention could be an appropriate active comparator. This would involve having two groups of participants undergoing exercise therapy, one following the standard set of exercises prescribed based on the literature review/expert recommendations and the other receiving a placebo intervention. The placebo could involve the patients performing actions that do not involve muscle activation, such as lying on their backs with their heads on the floor and moving their arms and legs or tapping their cheeks. By administering QL1706H in sequential cohorts with escalating doses, we aim to determine the maximum tolerated dose and the recommended dose for further studies. The Experimental: QL1706H Part 2 (Dose Exploration) arm focuses on exploring the pharmacokinetic parameters of QL1706H at different administration intervals. By testing the drug at various time points, we aim to understand its exposure levels, distribution, metabolism, and elimination in the body.    - Participant Group/Arm: Participants assigned to the VR-TrAC group will follow the Virtual Reality Training for Aggression.

The training is based on the Virtual Reality Aggression Prevention Training (VRAPT) protocol developed by Klein Tuente et al. The sessions are structured to target different stages of information processing related to aggressive behavior, including early and late stages. Participants will practice handling aggressive-inducing situations in virtual reality scenarios.

By comparing the outcomes of this group with the control group, researchers can evaluate the impact of VR-TRAC on aggression regulation.

2. Other: Care as Usual
   - Participant Group/Arm: Participants assigned to the Care as Usual group will receive standard care provided in the prison setting.
   - Intervention/Treatment: Care as Usual (CAU) in prison consists of treatments aimed at stabilizing psychological states, such as pharmacological treatment, supportive contact, or transfer to a Penitentiary Psychiatric Centre for necessary interventions.
   - Reasoning: This study arm serves as the control group for comparison with the VR-TRAC intervention group. By including a group that receives standard care practices in the prison environment, researchers can evaluate the additional benefits of the VR-TRAC program in reducing aggression beyond what is typically provided. For the narrow implants, the initial surgical phase of the implant placement will follow the regular protocol, with the placement of standard bone level Rex three-piece implants with an insertion torque above 35 Ncm. This will be followed by a second surgical procedure for the bone expansion and the placement of a wide abutment with a 10 mm height. This method will promote optimal positioning of the implant within the jawbone, allowing for predictable and stable bone support. For the interdental spaces, a fabricated connector will be incorporated to transfer forces efficiently to the rest of the prosthetic component to prevent bone loss. This study arm will include up to 14 patients, who will undergo the bone consumption and bone expansion procedures using the described surgical technique and novel implant design. Patients in the control group will receive the active comparator. They will also receive the Rex three-piece implant system but with a roughened transcortical portion for both the wide and narrow implant. The roughened design will promote optimal bone osseointegration, providing predictable and stable bone support. The active comparator group will include up to 14 patients who will undergo the bone consumption and bone expansion procedures using the same surgical technique described previously. Although both groups will use Rex implants, the control group will have a different surface treatment on the transcortical portion of the implant compared with the experimental arm.

Secondly, the bone expansion procedure of implant placement is designed to further stabilize the implants in narrow ridges. By choosing this study design, we can compare the effectiveness of the different surfaces in a controlled environment while minimizing potential confounds.

Pain Neuroscience Education (PNE) typically consists of patient education and communication that is built upon a thorough understanding of a patient's individual experience and social context. It aims to provide patients with an integrated biopsychosocial model of pain, which includes the role of the nervous system in transmitting pain messages, as well as psychosocial factors such as thoughts, fears, and behaviors that impact pain modulation. The goal of PNE is to help patients better understand their pain and take a more active role in managing it.

The Routine Education intervention should include information on postoperative care and expectations related to pain management, such as pain medications and other available treatments. The patients in this group should receive the same amount of time with either a physiotherapist or a physiotherapist assistant, similar to the PNE group.

The mRNA molecule contains the genetic code of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, and upon entry into the cell, it is translated into the spike protein. This technology utilizes lipid nanoparticle formulation for delivery. Both the vaccines have demonstrated a favorable safety profile. However, the mRNA-1283 vaccine (Janssen/Johnson & Johnson) differs from the Moderna and Pfizer vaccines in its composition. It is a single-lipid nano formulation compared to the lipid nanoparticle-based vaccines of Moderna and Pfizer vaccines, but it is more than 99% effective against moderate and severe COVID-19 disease.

The aim is to address the impaired muscle function, particularly in hip abductors, hamstrings, and GAST, in order to optimize joint motion. This is based on Kendall's Model as a theoretical frame. The intervention will involve joint mobilization at a grade 3-4 range of motion, using passive accessory and glide mobilization.
